comments.commentBody:
He's reachable, keep trying to get the chance to make a pitch... good luck.

CA is a great find based on my own exposure of six others. The people seems somehow willing to pay for what we have in spite of the GOP. It suffered under the looters for several nasty terms. Gov. Brown is a 'one off' from a dedicated family. Lots to clean up after, like Obama in that respect. Here he's likely to be appreciated with a second (4th), term. We've had worse and worser.. :-)

Dr. K,

Your last paragraph says it all. The California lab under the direction of Governor Brown has validated your theories for US economic recovery.

The American people have invested a great deal in developing the natural & human resources of this State. Think of the water projects that turned this natural desert into one of the Nation's biggest producers of food. Sure they are having water problems & the San Andreas fault makes engineering more challenging but CA certainly seems to attract a lot of very creative talent. Californians have made a remarkable contribution to this country & the national investments made have paid a handsome return.

America's taxpayers have agreed that California needs a North-South High Speed Rail system. And Governor Brown has made this his legacy project. California needs high speed rail but to a magnetic levitated (Maglev) person like me, it seems to be a huge mistake. Steel wheels pounding on steel rails is a maintenance challenge. There are only a couple of routes in the world that operate without a subsidy. California's HSR route will be very expensive to construct & construction will also require subsidization.

I have not talked to Gov. Brown but, if I could, I am convinced that he could be persuaded that a 300 mph superconducting Maglev system for carrying passengers & freight trucks in Maglev vehicles would be a better deal. www.magneticglide.com It is faster, much cheaper to build & operate than steel wheels.
VV in Boston, you took the words out of my mouth about disinterest.

The immigrant groups you mention (from past centuries) came here LEGALLY. They applied, they got in line. My four grandparents were among them (I have their naturalization and immigration papers to prove it!)

What is it that lefties can't understand about LEGAL vs. ILLEGAL? These folks are criminals. Most of these "children" are teens, and some are the very criminals and gang members they "claim" to be "fleeing".

When your (and my) grandparents came to the US, it was a booming economy, growing like mad, mostly empty and only about 100 million citizens. We NEEDED (legal) immigrants.

Today it is the opposite. We have 315 million people. Our cities are teeming. We are broke. We can't even provide jobs for our citizens let alone every suffering person in the WHOLE WORLD, which is what lefties would have us do.
TPS for Hondurans and Salvadorans who were already in US at time of Hurricane Mitch and earthquakes has been extended every 18 months for last dozen years.  Should it be extended in next few months?
I wore out that album.  Lots of memories indeed.

People from Africa don't represent a growing demographic key to American retail politics.

To say that Hondurans are more deserving of refugee status than children in Africa facing sexual enslavement or being press-ganged into becoming child soldiers is disgusting and based on nothing more than politics.

This is sheer madness.  At a time when we are seeking to reduce the unlawful flow of people over the Mexican border, the President's decision to send a team to process -- and thus speed up and magnify their immigration to the US -- runs directly against the wishes of Congress and the American people.   We live on a blighted planet, filled with nearly 8 billion people the great majority of whom live in countries at least as violent -- and often far more violent -- than Honduras and Guatemala.  What of the people of the Congo, five million of whom have died in the seemingly endless civil war that has raged there?  THE WHOLE WORLD -- with the exceptions of the still largely gated communities of Europe, Canada, Japan, Australia, New Zealand, Singapore and Israel -- would like to move here.  Do we want to take in the three billion people with nothing at all?  Of course we don't.  It would also destroy our ability to help others as our own society would morph into a Third World country.   It isn't cruel not to take in all the world's poor: it is a tragic necessity.
Haha. Just try it. Canada has secure borders and strict immigration laws.
My life can't be sustained indefinitely, either. Does that mean I should just go ahead and kill myself today?

It would be interesting to have a breakdown between income taxes and capital gains regarding which of the two has been a more important factor in raising revenues. Given the booming stock market and the plethora of start-up tech companies such as Facebook, I assume it is the latter. And this cannot and will not be sustained.

I agree that Honduras is perhaps no more hopeless than parts of Africa and the Middle East… But, things HAVE CHANGED in Honduras. San Pedro Sula is officially the most dangerous city in the world. I have spent some time near there recently and can truly understand why these people are so desperate. The violence there is so spectacular that it is almost incomprehensible to average Americans. The police are corrupt and dangerous. It was't like this only a few years ago…

I think your point about "Why Honduras" is valid, however. Perhaps it is because there are so many 'Catrachos' already living in the US. I believe there are about 640,000 Hondurans in the US; compared to only a few thousand Congolese, and less than 100,000 Palestinians, etc. The larger the community, the more political clout.

We obviously cannot take the entire world in. But Honduras is bad (really bad) and many families there have ties to the US already. I see no problem with Honduran-American families caring for their endangered relatives- especially the vulnerable children.

I get why the investment banks (fees) and the LBOs(ultra cheap financing, fobbing offs risks) are doing it, but I don't understand why the "investors" are doing it.

Why would these guys buy bonds that "everyone" thinks will eventually tank? I suppose in the main these are pension funds, bond funds and the like. I guess one can think of it as they willy nilly have cash that they have to put somewhere, assuming they are constrained to invest in bonds of some sort, they have filled their quota of other bonds (e.g treasuries, municipals) at the current market prices & relative value ratios, so, they are left with the crud and must buy.

So, the story looks like a global excess of savings over investments type of story (party because the fed manipulated the market, since it went out and bought up other bonds to compete with these guys). Also it means the govt by pulling back from positive RoR infrastructure where some of these savings could have been soaked up via deficit spending is doing a disservice.

So the pension funds end up lending money to fly by night LBO portfolio companies, money they are sure loose down the road, to the benefit of LBO billionaires and bank multimillionaires. At the same time public infrastructure that would power the broad economy sits undone because the tea party and politicians detest deficit spending.

Well, uh, South America doesn't have a constitution. Continents don't have constitutions. Countries have constitutions, sometimes. They aren't required even for countries.

But, why are you talking about South America? The minors under discussion are from Central America.

As a diehard non-fan, here's my two cents.  It's shocking, simply shocking, when men raised in a violent society, applauded for their ability to be physically intimidating, often on steroids and frequently brain damaged as a result of "sport" - just shocking - when they act badly.  Who would have expected it?
Read North Dallas 40 by Pete Gent.  That will take you inside the game.

Of course they're unskilled and uneducated ...  They're MINORS.  I'd say its better to have immigrant minors who can come, get an education, learn skills and who will better assimilate than adult immigrants.

The United States is not obligated to provide anything.  We have enough of our own children to care for.  Like Jesse above, I support President Obama on the majority of issues and voted for him twice.  Not here.
Whatever it takes to bring transparency back to court rulings is a good thing.  We're not in a democracy if we don't have that.

Cani, you should make sure you know what you saying before committing it to print.  It is common knowledge that a large portion of immigrants coming through Ellis Island were on the "government dole" the moment they arrived.  Especially, the Irish and Anglos who had countrymen waiting for them with government patronage.
So far few have turned up at their scheduled and promised hearings.  This is a scam to flood the US.
it is not our job to prevent other peoples' kids from riding trains or doing other foolish things. we have enough problems with our own children.

Whatever we can do to prevent kids from riding trains and all the other life threatening risks they're facing on their journey. We could stem the tide,though, by actually understanding and enforcing our current immigration and refugee laws.
The law that Bush passed was to stop human.child trafficing..in numbers in the hundreds...NOT the invasion in the hundreds of thousands

I just am not a parent who regulated screen time much. If they want to be on their phones on vacation and miss stuff that's not my problem. I have no idea if it's this attitude or simply luck but neither of my kids were immersed in their screens on our family vacations. They wanted to fully participate with the activities and family and they thus self regulated.
This is the first time I see Obama has done anything. He took a giant great step. I like him.

I loved constructivist math at first because it seemed like such a great way to get little ones, pre, kindergarten, and first graders to get math concepts and help them develop that spatial sense that really helps understand math. Go circles, go dots!  Then I found myself with a furiously bored second grader and discovered that the dots, circles and number lines were the ONLY way she was allowed to solve math problems until at least fifth grade.  Then we simply started teaching her the multiplication tables and standard algorithms ourselves. Then we found ourselves a good private school.

wvancamp,

Recently I had Telly Savalas as my avatar. Savalas began his television career as an executive director and then senior director of the news special events at ABC. He then became an executive producer for the Gillette Cavalcade of Sports where he gave Howard Cosell his first job in television.

Of course, Martin would not find this synchronicity unusual.

No need to do probably ---- lots of places to check your facts. But here's a nice graphic to show you where we actually did send billions in 2008 and 2012 (and not much has changed). Central American countries didn't get onto the top ten list.

http://abcnews.go.com/Politics/OTUS/fullpage/top-10-us-foreign-aid-recip...
